choices.A: The function goes through only the parse and executes phases.
choices.B: The function goes through the parse, bind, and execute phases.
choices.C: The function goes through the parse, bind, execute, and fetch phases.
choices.D: All the processing phases for the function are performed only at run time.
choices.E: Only the EXECUTE IMMEDIATE statement inside the function is parsed at run time.

A and E?
Wtf is a processing phase anw?

choices.C: SERVERPOINTS cannot be created in a PL/SQL block.
choices.A: A transaction can span multiple blocks.
choices.D: The END keyword signals the end of a PL/SQL block and automatically commits the transaction in the block.
choices.B: A block can contain only a single transaction.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about transactions in PL/SQL?

comments.content: Because it returns after the first iteration of the loop, so if more than 1 record exists, only the first is considered.

C is not correct as Oracle support attribute chaining that allows us to access record attribute returned by the call of highest_salary function.
And D is not correct due to reason decribed by pvpmagalhaes.

choices.D: It executes successfully and displays the names and salaries of all employees who earn the highest salary.
choices.C: It gives an error because the function call in DBMS_OUTPUT. PUT__LINE is not valid.
choices.A: It gives an error because the return type is not valid.
choices.E: It executes successfully but does not display the names and salaries of all employees who earn the highest salary.
choices.B: It gives an error because the record type is not defined within the function.

choices.E: To change a wrapped object, the original source code needs to be modified and then wrapped again.
choices.B: The PL/SQL wrapper detects and reports both syntax and semantic errors.
choices.C: When wrapping a package or object type, both the body and specification should be wrapped.
choices.D: When wrapping a package or object type, only the body should be wrapped, not the specification.
choices.F: To change a wrapped object, the wrapped code can be unwrapped, modified in a text file, and then wrapped again.
choices.A: The PL/SQL wrapper detects and reports only syntax errors.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about wrapping? (Choose three.)

comments.content: nope, A is not correct "Wrapping does not detect syntax or semantic error"

discussion.content:
I suppose A is correct. "If your input file contains syntactic errors, the PL/SQL Wrapper detects and reports them. However, the Wrapper cannot detect semantic errors because it does not resolve external references."
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/A57673_01/DOC/server/doc/PLS23/apd.htm
